target.name: IRF5
target.pathway: Type I IFN and pro-inflammatory cytokine production
target.biology: IRF5 is a master regulator transcription factor that controls pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNFα, IL-6, IL-12, IL-23), Type I IFN production, and autoantibody production in cell and activation-specific manner
target.genetic_validation: IRF5 functional risk variants associate with increased susceptibility to SLE, Sjögren's, RA, IBD, and SSc. Multiple GWAS studies identify IRF5 as autoimmune susceptibility gene
target.why_undruggable_before: Multiple activation steps and IRF family member homology made conventional approaches fail to effectively and selectively block IRF5

mechanism.description: Single binding event drives depletion of IRF5 protein and disrupts all IRF5 signaling, blocking cell-specific immune dysregulation while sparing normal cell function
mechanism.differentiation: First approach to effectively target this genetically validated transcription factor with potential for broad anti-inflammatory activity

market_opportunity.tam: >$45B market projected to grow to >$55B by 2029
market_opportunity.current_treatment: Anti-TNF, IL-6, IL-12/IL-23 antibodies, B cell targeting agents
market_opportunity.unmet_need: Only ~7% of patients have access to systemic advanced therapies, need for oral options in autoimmune diseases

bull_scenario.outcome: Deep IRF5 degradation with biomarker changes and good safety
bull_scenario.rationale: Would validate second oral degrader approach and advance lupus program

bear_scenario.rationale: Could delay or derail IRF5 program development
